title: brits party across the country as uk leaves the eu on historic night
story: Celebrations were held across the country from Cornwall to Cumbria — more than three years on from the referendum result.Some took to the streets, others hosted gatherings at home and pubs opened early so people could raise a glass.Many started partying long before pm, when Brexit was officially done.Scenes of jubilation erupted at a rally in Parliament Square as the clock struck pm and hardcore Brexit fans had tears in their eyes as they sang a rendition of God Save The Queen.A recording of Big Bens bong was played and flares were set off as a video screen displayed the words Were Out!Fireworks were set off around Britain and crowds gathered at parties to celebrate the historic moment.The dad-of-two, , added: “I call Brexit the great escape, freedom and independence day. I don’t think Brexit will be a miracle but we need democracy back from Brussels.“Brexit has been like an unreliable lover for these past four years. Are we free or not  I think we are now.”While thousands gathered in Parliament Square to mark Brexit, the celebratory mood was felt across the country.There were parties in Oxford, Ipswich, Stoke-on-Trent, York, Hull, Doncaster, Manchester, Liverpool and Plymouth.Excited Brexiteers posted images of themselves across social media — many under the #BrexitDay hashtag.The Union Jack was everywhere — flown in town centres, on strings of bunting and projected on to buildings. Revellers also dressed in Union Jack suits, tops, hats, glasses and even leggings.The atmosphere was buzzing in Boston, where landlord of the Robin Hood Inn, Rob Hancock, , was throwing a party, with free food and Land of Hope And Glory playing at last orders at pm.Rob said: “We are not racist but the town’s changed a lot since . The floodgates opened and we got absolutely overrun. There are  Eastern European shops in the town.”In Lympstone, Devon, avid Brexiteer Dave Tyrrell, , built a ft tower with a Brexit Bell to be rung at pm.Retired landscaper Dave said: “We’re not leaving Europe — Europe is a continent. We’re leaving the EU which is a political union — there’s a big dference.”Ray Singleton, , organised a Brexit event at his men’s club in Stapleford, Notts.He said: “The reason we are celebrating is because it’s a piece of British history. It is not a celebration to say, ‘We won and you lost’. It’s about bringing people together and to go forward together.”In staunchly pro—Leave Sunderland, retired company directors Stan Wildhirt, , and we, Dawn, , celebrated with a meal out and a glass of bubbly.Stan, who is half German, said: “I’m absolutely delighted. I love Europe but I hate the politicians.”But not everyone was in a celebratory mood and groups of Remainers staged candlelit vigils to express their sadness on Brexit day.Brexiteers from as far afield as Barnsley, South Yorkshire, were among the thousands in Parliament Square last night.There was a heavy police presence after earlier clashes on Whitehall between a far right group and pro-EU campaigners.But Brexit Party leader Nigel Farage told the crowd: “This is the greatest moment in modern British history.”

title: brexit guide travel holiday driving
story: The nations relationship with Europe will dramatically change as a result, but heres what will be dferent for most Brits, and everything you need to know about travel, visas and driving.The UK will leave the EU at pm tonight and we will then enter the so-called transition period until December , .This basically means most things for Brits will remain almost exactly the same for the next  months - as Britain thrashes out a new deal with the bloc which will come into play next year.Britain will still have to follow most of the EUs rules and regulations, but we should be free of them by .British citizens wont be EU citizens anymore, but will still be able to benefit from seamless travel throughout the bloc for the next few months.Goods will also continue to be traded freely throughout the UK and the EU for now.For the next  months Brits will be able to travel abroad just as easily as they can now.They will not yet need a visa to travel to EU countries.The European Commission has said that from , travellers will need to apply for an ETIASvisa waiver - much like when visiting America at the moment.ETIAS can be used for up to  days in a period of  days.It will cost roughly £ and be valid for three years - or up to the date of passport expiry.British pets will have the hardest time travelling through the EU and it could take up to  MONTHS to go through the new process.Pet passports will not be valid post- so owners need to contact their vets  month before travel.If you already have a passport, theres no need to worry, it will still be valid until the expiration date - regular rules apply.Brits who do need to renew their passport will be able to get their hands on a blue passport from early .By mid-, all new British passports will be blue.Mobile roaming charges will depend on your network - but most of the big networks have said they will continue to offer free roaming.EE, Vodafone, Three Mobile and O have all confirmed to The Sun that they have no current plans to reintroduce roaming charges.Brits on other networks should still check with their phone company for any extra charges.There is some good news for those facing charges - a new law which protects people from getting huge roaming charges without knowing about it has come into effect.Any charges above £ have to be opted into, so chat to your phone operator about it before your holiday.After , Brits may need to show aor onward ticket when travelling in the EU, as well as enough money for their holiday.There will also be separate lanes for Brits - no more using the EU, EEA and Swiss citizens queues.The pound jumped against the dollar and euro in the biggest three year rally in December as Boris won the election, so its looking good for Brits spending their money in Europe.But, you can never know what will happen to exchange rates tomorrow.The best way to get the most out of your hard earned cash on a European holiday, you should keep an eye on exchange rates in the weeks before you travel.European Health Insurance Cardswill still be valid until December  so Brits can be sure of free or reduced-cost medical treatment in the EU.After the end of the transition period, it depends on what deal Boris strikes with the EU.The governments website says: If the UK leaves the EU without a deal, your EHIC might not be valid anymore.If you do want to drive in Europe after , youll have to get hold of an International Driving Permit.They only cost £. and can be picked up from a post office, but make sure you check which one the country you are visiting requires - there are dferent types.For Brits living in Europe, driving on their UK drivers licence, they will need to be swapped over for a local licence before December , .British expats living where in the EU can stay on in their home country.However, there might be a few administrative hoops they have to jump through depending on what their country asks for.That doesnt mean they will have the same access to move to other EU countries post-.The  million Europeans in the UK can still live here after Friday - but they will need to apply for settled status or pre-settled status by December .The UK will move over to an Australian-style points based system as soon as the transition period ends, meaning hopeful immigrants will have to fulfil certain criteria including education, work background and language skills.After we finally leave, Boris Johnson will face up to the EU to secure a trade deal in the  month transition period.The EU has been dragging their heels, and swearing they cant get a deal done by December .Boris has said in no uncertain terms he will not allow the transition period to be extended beyond December .US President Donald Trump has also signalled hes ready to sign a fantastic new trade deal with the UK.The talks with the US will run at the same time as the UK.Post :Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit britain finally leaves eu
story: w.mantis  Brexit: Britain finally leaves the EU as Boris Johnson hails moment of hope n Four years after the referendum, the UK will wake up as a non-EU member after  years - and the Prime Minister called for the nation to come together after Brexit nBritain has finally left the EU, ushering in a healing process to bring the country back together after Brexit. nThe UK is waking up to its first full day as a non-EU member in  years after formally leaving the bloc at pm.  nNearly four years after voters decided by % to % to quit, politicians from all sides called on Leavers and Remainers to set aside their dferences, as the nation immediately entered an -month transition.  n An hour before Britain’s exit, Boris Johnson, who led the  Vote Leave campaign, said in a pre-recorded TV address: “Tonight we are leaving the European Union. n“For many people this is an astonishing moment of hope, a moment they thought would never come, and there are many of course who feel a sense of anxiety and loss.  n“And then of course there is a third group – perhaps the biggest – who had started to worry that the whole political wrangle would never come to an end.   n“I understand all those feelings and our job as the Government – my job – is to bring this country together now and take us forward.”   nBoris Johnson address the nation about Brexit  n   nHe added: “When I look at the potential of this country waiting to be unleashed I know that we can turn this opportunity into a stunning success - and whatever the bumps in the road ahead, I know that we will succeed.  n“We have obeyed the people, we have taken back the tools of self-government.  n“Now is the time to use those tools to unleash the full potential of this brilliant country and to make better the lives of everyone in every corner of our United Kingdom.”  n Outgoing Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said: “The choice of which path we take for a post-Brexit Britain now lies before us. n“Whatever side we took in the Brexit debate we now need to bring the country together to shape our common future.”  n  n Brexit: What happens now after UK officially leaves the EU  nEarlier, the Prime Minister held a symbolic Cabinet meeting in Sunderland - the first city to announce its referendum result after the vote on June , .  nLater, Mr Johnson flew back to London to host a low-key reception in Downing Street.  nGuests included Cabinet Ministers, No staff, officials who were involved in the Brexit negotiations and supporters of the battle to leave the EU.  nThey were served English sparkling wine and canapes including fillet of lamb on toast, Shropshire blue cheese, beef and Yorkshire pudding with horseradish sauce, mushrooms tarts and roast chicken skewers.  n  n   nAn illuminated clock counting down to pm was projected onto Downing Street.  nOther buildings in Whitehall were lit up in red, white and blue, including the Ministry of Defence, Ministry of Justice, HM Revenue and Customs, the Scotland Office, the Wales Office and the Cabinet Office.  nBut while there were pleas for unity, EU supporters staged protests in Liverpool, Doncaster and Harrogate while Brexiteers in Westminster chanted anti-EU slogans.  nAs Union flags flew in Parliament Square and The Mall, the UK flag was lowered from its pole at the European Council building - formally bringing an end to the UK’s membership.  n  n Jeremy Corbyn gives Brexit message declaring apostoday is only the beginningapos  nEuropean Council President Charles Michel, the former PM of Belgium, admitted: “Today is an exceptional day for the European Union and today probably we have mixed feelings.  n“It’s never a happy moment when someone leaves but we are opening a new chapter, and we will devote all our energy  years - and the Prime Minister called for the nation to come together after BrexitShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan Bloom:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Britain has finally left the EU, ushering in a healing process to bring the country back together after Brexit.The UK is waking up to its first full day as a non-EU member in  years after formally leaving the bloc at pm. Nearly four years after voters decided by % to % to quit, politicians from all sides called on Leavers and Remainers to set aside their dferences, as the nation immediately entered an -month transition.An hour before Britain’s exit, Boris Johnson, who led the  Vote Leave campaign, said in a pre-recorded TV address: “Tonight we are leaving the European Union.“For many people this is an astonishing moment of hope, a moment they thought would never come, and there are many of course who feel a sense of anxiety and loss. “And then of course there is a third group – perhaps the biggest – who had started to worry that the whole political wrangle would never come to an end.  “I understand all those feelings and our job as the Government – my job – is to bring this country together now and take us forward.”   He added: “When I look at the potential of this country waiting to be unleashed I know that we can turn this opportunity into a stunning success - and whatever the bumps in the road ahead, I know that we will succeed. “We have obeyed the people, we have taken back the tools of self-government. “Now is the time to use those tools to unleash the full potential of this brilliant country and to make better the lives of everyone in every corner of our United Kingdom.”Outgoing Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said: “The choice of which path we take for a post-Brexit Britain now lies before us.“Whatever side we took in the Brexit debate we now need to bring the country together to shape our common future.”  Earlier, the Prime Minister held a symbolic Cabinet meeting in Sunderland - the first city to announce its referendum result after the vote on June , . Later, Mr Johnson flew back to London to host a low-key reception in Downing Street. Guests included Cabinet Ministers, No staff, officials who were involved in the Brexit negotiations and supporters of the battle to leave the EU. They were served English sparkling wine and canapes including fillet of lamb on toast, Shropshire blue cheese, beef and Yorkshire pudding with horseradish sauce, mushrooms tarts and roast chicken skewers.  Mr Johnson gave an eight minute speech to supporters and staff. But Mr Cummings was overcome with emotion, appearing close to tears and rubbing his head and face.After a y pause, he said: Lots of people in this room know what happened. Thankyou. An illuminated clock counting down to pm was projected onto Downing Street. Other buildings in Whitehall were lit up in red, white and blue, including the Ministry of Defence, Ministry of Justice, HM Revenue and Customs, the Scotland Office, the Wales Office and the Cabinet Office. But while there were pleas for unity, EU supporters staged protests in Liverpool, Doncaster and Harrogate while Brexiteers in Westminster chanted anti-EU slogans. As Union flags flew in Parliament Square and The Mall, the UK flag was lowered from its pole at the European Council building - formally bringing an end to the UK’s membership.  European Council President Charles Michel, the former PM of Belgium, admitted: “Today is an exceptional day for the European Union and today probably we have mixed feelings. “It’s never a happy moment when someone leaves but we are opening a new chapter, and we will devote all our energy to building a stronger and more ambitious European Union.” EU leaders issued a stark warning that shting away from the bloc’s rules will leave the UK with weakened access to the single market. Mr Michel said: “The more the UK will erge from the EU standards, the less the access to the single market they will have.” European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen added: “Britain will become a third country, and for all third countries, the following applies - only those who acknowledge the rules of the common market can benefit fully from the common market.” She warned: “We want to have the best possible relationship with the United Kingdom but it will never be as good as membership.”Senior Cabinet Minister Michael Gove admitted trade with the EU would not be “frictionless” after the transition deal ends on December .He said: “We want trade to be as frictionless as possible but the EU is clear, you can only have fully frictionless tradeyou accept all of their rules,you accept all their laws, you are subordinate to their judges, you are subordinate to their political structures.”  The Government wants to strike a trade deal with the EU before the transition period finishes. But ministers also plan to target a pact with the US. American Ambassador to Britain Woody Johnson hailed a “historic day in British history”. “On behalf of the United States Government, I would like to wish the United Kingdom every success as you chart a new path outside of the European Union,” he said. “America shares your optimism and excitement about the many opportunities the future will bring.”  One of the key drivers of the Leave vote was record migration from Europe through EU freedom of movement. Labour leadership hopeful Keir Starmer signalled he will bring back freedom of movementhe becomes PM. Vowing to “make the case” for migration’s benefits and free movement, he said in a speech at Westminster Cathedral Hall: ”I want families to be able to live together, whether that’s in Europe or here, and I want people in this country, in the United Kingdom, to be able to go and study in Europe just as they can now and people in Europe to be able to come and study here.” Asked directlyhe would “bring back” free movement for EU citizens, he told the Mirror: “Yes, of course - bring back, argue for, challenge.” Mr Starmer, who led the Shadow Cabinet battle to push Mr Corbyn towards backing a second referendum, said: “We’ve had the Brexit ide - it’s gone deep. “We’ve now got to win the peace, we’ve got to win what comes next.” Mr Johnson now faces huge pressure to deliver on his  referendum and  election promises. He pledged £million a week extra for the NHS during the Brexit battle and a boost to Britain’s economy from leaving the bloc. During the run-up to December’s general election, he also made a string of promises to the North and Midlands, where voters handed him a thumping Commons majority.But his commitments to the North  and Midlands will be questionedhe scraps the planned HS railway, which will slash journey times and boost capacity between London and Birmingham, and Leeds and Manchester. He is also under pressure to cut net migration, with many Leave supporters opting to quit the bloc so the numbers heading to the UK can be reduced. Latest figures show annual net migration - the dference between the numbers coming to the UK and those leaving each year - running at ,. The PM also faces renewed calls to tackle climate change, having vowed to “lead the global fight against climate change by delivering on our world-leading target of Net Zero greenhouse gas emissions by ”.

story: w.mantis  Brexit: What happens now after the UK officially leaves the EU n Britain will wake up on Saturday morning to a new era - but what will it mean for you and your loved ones  Heres a round up of what happens next n More than three-and-a-half years after the country voted to leave the European Union, the UK will wake up to a new era on Saturday morning.  nThat historic decision back in June  has ided the nation and will be greeted by a mixture of joy, sadness and relief - but also uncertainty.  nWhat does our departure actually mean for our economy, our laws and our place on the world stage   nHow - and when - will the biggest constitutional change in half a century impact on the lives of you and your loved ones   n Here we take a look at what Brexit means for you: nWhat has changed   n  n   nNot much. Although this is the legal moment the UK becomes the first nation ever to leave the EU, in practical terms you’ll notice very little dference.  nThat’s because we are in a ‘transition period’ until the end of the year during which the UK will continue to follow EU rules - although we won’t have any say in them as British MEPs have lost their jobs and the UK won’t attend any more summits. It will also keep paying into the EU’s budget.  nBlue passports stripped of EU branding will start being issued to all new applicants, instead of the old burgundy ones, and m special p coins will enter circulation.  n Jeremy Corbyn gives Brexit message declaring apostoday is only the beginningapos   nWhat happens next   n  n   nThe UK can now formally begin trade talks with other countries, like the US and Australia, so they are ready to kick in at the end of the year.  nThe Government will be hoping for some quick wins so it can show it is making a success of Brexit.  nA new team within No , headed by the PM’s chief Europe adviser David Frost, will lead the UK’s trade talks with the EU, our biggest trading partner.  nThey’re only expected to get going properly in March after the EU agrees its negotiating “mandate” - and many believe they won’t be finished on time.  nCan the transition period be extended   nThe Brexit deal says the transition period can go on for another two years - until the end of . But the government passed a law banning any extension to show how serious it is about leaving.  nBut it can still change its mind right up to the end of June. Beyond that, the  December becomes a hard deadline.  nWe will continue to follow EU rules for the rest of the year and start paying our £bn ‘orce bill’ to the EU which stretch for several years. n Jubilant Brexit backers descend on Parliament for aposmost exciting moment of their leapos   nWill the trade talks be a success   n  n   nThe Government hopes so as they were touted as one of the biggest benefits of Brexit, but they have very little time.  nAny deals with other countries are likely to require controversial trade-offs, such as any agreement with the US over food standards and the NHS.  nEU officials are sceptical we’ll be able to strike a deal within the year.  nIf we do, there will be a new set of rules from  January .  nIf not, we could crash out on ‘WTO terms’ - the basic rules that slap high tarfs and restrictions on trade.  nWhat will Boris Johnson do next   nNo is desperate to move on from Brexit and to focus on domestic policy. The PM will have a big Cabinet reshuffle and is expected to make a string of announcements that benefit new Tory constituencies in the Midlands and North.  nHe won his election victory on a promise of “levelling up” the British economy with greater investment into areas devastated by a decade of Tory austerity.  nBut with tough trade talks and another looming deadline, Brexit isn’t going away, eventhe PM has restricted parliamentary scrutiny of the next phase.   nWill our economy be stronger after Brexit   n  n   nThe full consequences of Brexit are uncertain. Much depends on whether we get a trade deal with the EU. Without one, the UK will “fall out” onto damaging WTO terms.  nEvenMr Johnson manages to strike a Canada-style agreement with the EU, the Treasury’s own forecasts estimate that Britain’s economy would be .% smaller - more than £bn a year - after  years than it would bewe’d stayed in the EU.  nThe Government claims the economy could be boosted by trade deals with other countries - but the long-promised “Brexit idend” looks unlikely. n Inside Boris Johnsonaposs exclusive Brexit bash with English sparkling wine but no champagne   nAnd what about our place on the world stage   nMr Johnson has promised post-Brexit Britain will be an outward-looking global power, building on relationships with old Commonwealth allies and newer “Five Eyes” security partners.  nBy leaving the EU we may have more freedom, but we will also have markedly less clout in a world where the three major global hubs are the US, China and the EU.  n For decades Britain saw itself as a bridge between Europe and the US - but with Brexit and Donald Trump those relationships are under strain. nAnd while we remain a major global economy, our departure from the single market makes us less attractive to many foreign investors.  nIf the UK splinters after Brexit, with Scotland going it alone, it could put at risk its right to a seat on the United Nations Security Council.  nWill I still be able to travel to Europe   n  n   nUK nationals will still be able to live, work and drive in the EU as they do now until the end of the transition. Future travel restrictions will be hammered out over the next  months.  nYou won’t need a visa from  January you’re a tourist. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMore than three-and-a-half years after the country voted to leave the European Union, the UK will wake up to a new era on Saturday morning. That historic decision back in June  has ided the nation and will be greeted by a mixture of joy, sadness and relief - but also uncertainty. What does our departure actually mean for our economy, our laws and our place on the world stage  How - and when - will the biggest constitutional change in half a century impact on the lives of you and your loved ones Here we take a look at what Brexit means for you:What has changed   Not much. Although this is the legal moment the UK becomes the first nation ever to leave the EU, in practical terms you’ll notice very little dference. That’s because we are in a ‘transition period’ until the end of the year during which the UK will continue to follow EU rules - although we won’t have any say in them as British MEPs have lost their jobs and the UK won’t attend any more summits. It will also keep paying into the EU’s budget. Blue passports stripped of EU branding will start being issued to all new applicants, instead of the old burgundy ones, and m special p coins will enter circulation.  The UK can now formally begin trade talks with other countries, like the US and Australia, so they are ready to kick in at the end of the year. The Government will be hoping for some quick wins so it can show it is making a success of Brexit. A new team within No , headed by the PM’s chief Europe adviser David Frost, will lead the UK’s trade talks with the EU, our biggest trading partner. They’re only expected to get going properly in March after the EU agrees its negotiating “mandate” - and many believe they won’t be finished on time. Can the transition period be extended  The Brexit deal says the transition period can go on for another two years - until the end of . But the government passed a law banning any extension to show how serious it is about leaving. But it can still change its mind right up to the end of June. Beyond that, the  December becomes a hard deadline. We will continue to follow EU rules for the rest of the year and start paying our £bn ‘orce bill’ to the EU which stretch for several years.  The Government hopes so as they were touted as one of the biggest benefits of Brexit, but they have very little time. Any deals with other countries are likely to require controversial trade-offs, such as any agreement with the US over food standards and the NHS. EU officials are sceptical we’ll be able to strike a deal within the year. If we do, there will be a new set of rules from  January . If not, we could crash out on ‘WTO terms’ - the basic rules that slap high tarfs and restrictions on trade. What will Boris Johnson do next  No is desperate to move on from Brexit and to focus on domestic policy. The PM will have a big Cabinet reshuffle and is expected to make a string of announcements that benefit new Tory constituencies in the Midlands and North. He won his election victory on a promise of “levelling up” the British economy with greater investment into areas devastated by a decade of Tory austerity. But with tough trade talks and another looming deadline, Brexit isn’t going away, eventhe PM has restricted parliamentary scrutiny of the next phase.  Will our economy be stronger after Brexit   The full consequences of Brexit are uncertain. Much depends on whether we get a trade deal with the EU. Without one, the UK will “fall out” onto damaging WTO terms. EvenMr Johnson manages to strike a Canada-style agreement with the EU, the Treasury’s own forecasts estimate that Britain’s economy would be .% smaller - more than £bn a year - after  years than it would bewe’d stayed in the EU. The Government claims the economy could be boosted by trade deals with other countries - but the long-promised “Brexit idend” looks unlikely.  And what about our place on the world stage  Mr Johnson has promised post-Brexit Britain will be an outward-looking global power, building on relationships with old Commonwealth allies and newer “Five Eyes” security partners. By leaving the EU we may have more freedom, but we will also have markedly less clout in a world where the three major global hubs are the US, China and the EU.For decades Britain saw itself as a bridge between Europe and the US - but with Brexit and Donald Trump those relationships are under strain.And while we remain a major global economy, our departure from the single market makes us less attractive to many foreign investors. If the UK splinters after Brexit, with Scotland going it alone, it could put at risk its right to a seat on the United Nations Security Council. Will I still be able to travel to Europe   UK nationals will still be able to live, work and drive in the EU as they do now until the end of the transition. Future travel restrictions will be hammered out over the next  months. You won’t need a visa from  January you’re a tourist. But British citizens will no longer be able to spend more than three months in the EU without applying for a work or study visa. You may also need to show aticket, that you have enough money for your stay, and stop using EU passport lanes at European borders. The UK will bring in its own immigration system to control EU migration from the end of the year - though the Government always had the option of reducing immigration from outside the EU, but chose not to for economic reasons.  WhatI fall ill on holiday   You will be able to continue getting treatment in EU hospitals as you do now until the end of the transition period. After that, the European Health Insurance Card , which gives Brits access to EU healthcare in an emergency, will no longer work. There will not be one EU-wide regime on healthcare so it is up to the UK to strike “reciprocal” health cover with inidual states. A pact with Spain - home to , British expats - is likely to be among the first agreed. Butno deals to look after each others’ citizens are struck, British travellers will require adequate health insurance, while EU migrants here will be charged £ a year to use the NHS.  What will happen to EU citizens  EU citizens can continue arriving freely in the UK to live and work until  December . But they must apply by June  for “settled status”, which gives them the right to stay in the UK. Those who haven’t lived in the UK for five continuous years have to apply twice - first for “pre-settled status”, then again for settled status when the hit the five-year mark. After the transition period, new EU migrants will be subject to a points-based immigration system. They will have to prove their skills and probably earn a minimum salary.  Will I still get my workersapos rights  The Government will set its own workers’ rights after the transition with many fearing they will be watered down - or dropped entirely. Currently the EU has limits on night work and requirements for daily and weekly rest breaks. It also sets a -hour limit on the working week while giving employees the right to four weeks’ paid annual leave, plus bank holidays. Some expect anti-age discrimination measures to be removed - meaning there will be little or no protection for younger or older workers. Agency workers could be stripped of their right to equal treatment as permanent staff. Ministers have said they will continue maternity rights but there are no guarantees.  What  changes for me from January    You will no longer be guaranteed free mobile phone roaming in the EU as the issue will be left to operators. Duty free willon flights and boats to the EU. But there are likely to be some checks on lorries and vehicles crossing the Channel that could lead to delays. There will also be new checks on goods crossing between Britain and Northern Ireland under the terms of the Irish backstop. You may also need an international driving permit as well as a ‘green cardapos to prove you have the right car insurance and a GB bumper sticker. Pet owners can carry on bringing their animals to the EU on ‘pet passports’ until December, but after will need to obtain a health certicate. The Supreme Court will be the highest court of appeal in the UK and there will be no direct role for the European Court of Justice in British le.  Is the Union under threat  Boris Johnson has spoken about the “awesome foursome” of England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.But Brexit may be the catalyst which breaks up the country, with nationalist sentiment on the rise in Scotland and a steady march towards a reunied Ireland bolstered by the limited border down the Irish Sea. Wales - which backed Brexit - is more integrated with England than the other “celtic” nations. ButScotland goes it alone and prospers then Wales could want to follow a similar path.

Last summer thousands of Remainers and Brexiteers met to talk about big issues and discover what they had in common – you can see the results at britain-talks.mirror This summer, we plan to repeat the experiment, from Friday June  to Sunday June . We’ve partnered with the Jo Cox Foundation’s Great Get Together, and organised our event on the same weekend for maximum impact. The Foundation is named after murdered MP Jo Cox, who said: “We have far more in common than that which ides us.” As the fourth anniversary of the Brexit vote approaches, Britain Talks feels more important than ever. Deltapoll interviewed , and the results also showed % of us think the UK is continuing to “get more ided”, while just % see change happening the other way.  Asked which three issues most ide our country, the biggest is still Brexit, which % of people see as the greatest ider. This is down from % last year, suggesting the issue is becoming less isive. But other issues are continuing to split the nation – wealth , immigrationand left-right politics . As one of our first ever Britain Talks participants, Jon Conor Lyons says there are new isions growing. “After the general election it did feel people were becoming even more entrenched,” he says. “You saw people saying, ‘ you voted this way, you’re an idiot’.  “And here in the north, where the Tories made gains, there is that danger that we’ll see more ision. If we don’t talk about that and find ways to talk about the choices we’ve made, things will become more entrenched.” Catherine Anderson, CEO of the Jo Cox Foundation, said: “It has never been more important than it is today to get Britain talking again. Today emotions will be running high. Some people feeling fearful about the future post-Brexit, others excited. But we are going to have to come together as a country and sooner rather than later. “Britain Talks will play a huge part in that healing process and we’re delighted that it will again go hand-in-hand with the Great Get Together on June - when we remember Jo Cox’s words that we all have ‘more in common than that which ides us’.” What Britain Talks participants said... Jon Conor Lyons, , Student, Labour councillor and Remainer from Manchester, met Ada Pratt, , Tory Brexiter and retired nurse, from Littleborough, Greater Manchester. Jon said: “I didn’t think Ada and I would get to know each other in the way we have. We’ve found a lot in common and we wouldn’t have done that any other way. “A lot of the toxicity comes from social media, where you’ve taken the human element out, you’re just reducing people down to their politics. You have to move past that and see them as a person. They’re not a monster with dferent views than you. They’re not someone you can just dismiss. “People are more than just their politics but the deep isions in our society can stop us seeing that. “I wasn’t sure what we would have in common but there’s a lot. We’re both engaged with politics and we’re both proactive in our communities. It’s challenged the perceptions I had about meeting an older lady from a town. “I’m so glad I got involved.”  Ada added: “Meeting Jon was interesting because of who he is but also because he’s young. It feels like we’re always getting told that old people have ruined everything. But Jon has given me hope for the future. “He was easy to talk to, and he wasn’t bigoted or judgemental. We found out that we’ve come from quite similar backgrounds, from working class families, so we share values in some ways. “Jon was happy to listen, and it made me realise that young people do have a lot to contribute, a lot to say. It wasn’t just talking, it was seeing how his le is, it made it easier to understand what le is like for a lot of his generation. “Church bells might ring out on  January - but we still have plenty to talk about. We need to find ways to move forward as a nation don’t we ”  Abi Reader, , Dairy farmer, from rural south Wales met Sarah King, , a vegan fashion blogger from Bristol. Abi said: “Sarah and I don’t live that far from each other, but our lives couldn’t be more dferent. Taking part was about seeing the bigger picture - discussing the big issues rather than getting stuck in the usual arguments. I think Sarah and I both looked at things from each other’s perspective. “You don’t just bump into people with completely dferent views to yours, you have to make an effort to find them and be ready to listen. It was a big deal to have Sarah visit my farm, it was a really special thing to do. “One of the biggest things I took from the experience was this feeling of pride. I realised how rich my le was. “I’ve not become a vegan - I have salad with my ham and that’s as far as it goes! But I did enjoy listening and talking through some of the issues.”  Sarah responded: “I would like to stay in touch because it was such a positive experience. It was great to meet someone completely out of my normal circle but open to chat, and Abi was so welcoming. To have that chance to communicate was great. “You do see a lot of confrontation on so called debates on TV - where they pit people against each other but there is no real dialogue. The election has made things worse, it’s closed down conversations. It happened so quickly, there was the sudden sht – I’m that team and you’re this team. “There is still a lot to talk about. As veganism becomes more mainstream it’s on the news agenda more but there are lots of tensions within the vegan community, especially around class and race and it would be good to discuss some of these things too. It was interesting to speak to someone who is an authority in their field.” Bob Roberts, , fisherman and business owner, Scarborough, Yorkshire met Razan Alsous, , Syrian refugee and business owner, Huddersfield, West Yorkshire. Bob said:: “Meeting Razan certainly made me think - when she explained her story you can’t help but think about why people make a journey like that, what brings people who really are in need of help to the UK. There still has to be a balance but on a human level, talking to Razan you can completely understand why you would flee and how hard it is to start again. “It’s very dferent talking face to face, being with someone. You can’t just dismiss someone’s experiences when they’re sitting there with you. “You’re two humans sitting together, not just two lots of ideas. And you can’t write off someone’s views when you’re sat having a cup of tea. “Meeting Razan confirmed some of my views and gave me a chance to think about some others. I’m still a big believer that immigration policies have to be strengthened. “Brexit is such a dficult issue and for me there are particular ideas we’ve got to discuss. We’ve got a very signicant coastline, that will be right at the forefront of negotiations, and we’ve got to be ready for that.”  Razan said: “Britain Talks was a really good experience for me. I don’t always get to meet people I can talk to about politics, people who might have a dferent idea to me, so meeting Bob was really important. “It was good to hear someone’s real views - someone being honest and direct - instead of just general views, I was getting to hear about things from a new angle. “Talking can help you think about how you see things and also to make decisions - to think more about how you want to do things. Are you deciding for yourself or for others  “Having these debates has to be better for society. And I hope it presented a more positive story about who refugees are to the media. As refugees we aren’t always good at doing that. There’s a lot of bad feeling towards immigrants and refugees and we need to talk about that and where it comes from. “There’s no problem with being dferent or having a dferent point of view than anyone ,we can talk to each other with respect,we can sit down and really listen to each other. “There is a lot we don’t know about each other’s le and we need to find out more so we can find out how we can live together. Because the world is changing, we’ve got to change the model of how we live together and understanding has got to be part of that. “Bob was so nice and respectful, and we did have more in common than we think. Deep down we both want the same things, like most people do.” Stevie Sinclair, , Rangers superfan and thalidomide campaigner met Stephen McBride, , Celtic fan and publican in Glasgow. Stevie said: “It was very worthwhile for me. Yes, we do have a rivalry through football but being a similar age, from a similar generation, we were able to share a lot of football memories too. Steve was very knowledgable, so it was easy to spend time with him. “It’s not every day you’ll see a Celtic and Rangers fan taking a drink together but it was good, we had a lot to talk about and I’m really glad I got the chance to do that. “There is ision everywhere - whether it’s football or the politics, we all have our traditions and views. We need to talk about politics and these things between ourselves, to work out how we make sense of things without things getting silly. “We need to keep talking and meeting - not just talking on social media. You see friends falling out on there. We should be able to share our opinions, embracing things that are dferent, chatting more to more people to find out what people really think, rather than just assuming we know. “Meeting in real le means you can stop things getting heated, have a laugh - humour goes a long way.”

title: gp who took over harold
story: w.mantis  GP who took over Harold Shipmans surgery still dealing with legacy  years on n EXCLUSIVE: Dr Amir Hannan took over Harold Shipmans GP surgery and battled to regain patients trust. Here he tells the Mirror how his heart skipped when he stumbled across the couch on which Dr Death had murdered patients n As a newly qualied GP looking for his first post, Dr Amir Hannan thought the cosy little surgery advertised simply as ‘ Market Street, Cheshire’ looked perfect.  nIt was only when he phoned and asked where to send his application that his we realised who used to run the practice.  nThe rookie doctor was stepping into the shoes of Dr Death. It was the surgery in Hyde run by Harold Shipman who murdered around  of his patients, making him the most prolic serial killer in history.  nThe old mill town, seven miles from Manchester, was devastated by the evil doctor’s crimes. He worked and killed there from  until he was caught in , and every resident knew someone whose le had been cruelly cut short by Shipman.  nIt was on January ,  –  years ago today, that he was convicted and jailed for le for murdering  of his patients.  nDr Hannan arrived in Hyde nine months later, and was soon all too well aware of what he was letting himself in for.  n  n aposI still feel upset at familiesapos cries as Harold Shipman was convicted of murderapos  n How Ted Bundy, Peter Sutclfe, Levi Bellfield duped lovers into covering up crimes   nHe says: “The day before I started, my we and I were watching TV and it came on the news – they were in  Market Street in Hyde and there were a whole load of elderly men and women all sat on the floor of the waiting room. They were angry, protesting that a new doctor was going to be foisted upon them. I just thought, ‘Oh my God – I am walking into a war zone’.  n“That gave me my first taste of what was going to come. I arrived to find that Shipman’s we had turned up the night before and taken the computer system away because it had been owned by Shipman.”  nGiving his new premises a thorough examination, like any good doctor, it was Dr Hannan’s heart which suddenly skipped a beat when he stumbled across the couch on which Shipman had murdered a number of his patients.  n  nHow aposoriginalapos Harold Shipman murdered hundreds of patients - and got away with it  n The nine seconds that exposed Harold Shipman as Britainaposs most notorious serial killer  nHe says: “There was a side room off the surgery that had the couch in it. He had put the patients in there, murdered them, shut the door and then carried on his consultations and nobody knew. So there I am on day one, I have no computer, and that couch had to go immediately.”  nShipman hid in plain sight, murdering mostly elderly female patients. His killing method was injecting diamorphine, a pharmaceutical heroin. Born in Nottingham in , as a boy he was very close to his domineering mother Vera.  nChillingly given his subsequent killing spree, he was fascinated by how morphine eased Vera’s pain when she was dying from lung cancer.  n  n   nHis mother died aged just  when Shipman was . Determined to become a doctor, he graduated from Leeds School of Medicine in , four years after marrying Primrose Oxtoby, with whom he would have four children. After finishing his training, he joined a practice in Todmorden, West Yorks.  nShipman’s career almost came to an abrupt and early halt. He became addicted to the painkiller Pethidine and was caught forging prescriptions. He left the practice and entered drug rehab, hit with a fine and a conviction for forgery. But the General Medical Council decided no further action should be taken, as did the Home Office.  nShipman was free toto the profession and in  secured a post at the Donneybrook practice in Hyde. He became known as a hardworking, honest GP and in , after more than a decade at Donneybrook, set out on his own, starting up the practice in Market Street.  n  nHe was followed by devoted patients, many of whom would later refuse to believe the man they thought of as a pillar of the community was an angel of death.   nIt was March  when it became apparent Shipman’s elderly patients were dying at a higher rate than expected and in very similar circumstances – usually fully clothed, sitting up in an armchair or reclining on a settee.  nDespite respected members of the community – a funeral director, a taxi driver and another GP, becoming suspicious, a preliminary police investigation said there was no cause for concern.  nShipman’s records appeared to be in order and little wonder, for the doctor had carefully falsied them.  n  nIn the end the family GP would finally be snared by his own greed. In June ,  year-old former mayoress of Hyde Kathleen Grundy was discovered dead hours after Shipman visited, leaving relatives perplexed as she had appeared to be in good health.  nThey were further alarmed when they discovered her will had been changed, leaving her whole estate, worth £,, to Shipman.  nThe doctor insisted no autopsy was necessary but Kathleen’s daughter Angela Woodruff refused to accept Dr Shipman’s explanations.  nHer mother’s body was exhumed and a postmortem revealed she died from a morphine overdose administered within three hours of her death.  n  nMatching the time frame in which Shipman had visited her, the doctor’s home was searched and medical records, a strange collection of jewellery and the typewriter used to forge the will were uncovered.  nPolice soon learned the calculating killer had urged many families to get their loved ones cremated to hide his crimes, produced falsied medical notes when questions were raised – and even pretended to call the emergency services in front of relatives only to “cancel” the ambulance after he pronounced the patient dead.  nShipman went on trial at Preston crown court charged with  counts of murder and one count of forgery and was found guilty on all charges. n  nThe disgraced doctor was given a whole le sentence and four years later, he hung himself at Wakefield Prison, aged .  nHe remains the only British doctor ever to be found guilty of murdering his patients.  nThe subsequent Shipman Inquiry looked into how he had got away with killing for so long, and why he had done it. But in the end its chair Dame Janet Smith said: “I think Shipman’s crimes were without motive.  n“The psychiatrists warn me that it is possible that, in Shipman’s own mind, there was a conscious motivation. All I can say is that there is no evidence of any of the features that I have observed, in my experience as a judge, that motivate murderers.”  n  n nWhat is clear is that Shipman’s killing spree shattered trust among his patients in Hyde – which Dr Hannan has been rebuilding.  nThe -year-old GP says: “When the story first broke it was complete disbelief. People said no, you go to your doctor for him to help you, not for him to murder you.  n“This is a deprived area. People here die  years earlier than the national average which is one of the reasons nobody picked up on the excess deaths. It was almost, what do you expect  You live in Hyde.  n“It might not be talked about on the news any more, but it is still very vivid in people’s minds and it causes distress and mental health problems. I am still dealing with the fallout of Shipman to this very day. It doesn’t go away.”  nIYA Crime Widget  nIngrid Brindle was one of Shipman’s patients. “I thought he was an excellent doctor because I had a long-term medical condition and he gave me everything I needed,” she says. “I really thought he was excellent and so did a lot of other people.”  nIt was important for Dr Hannan to regain the trust of his patients. It was one simple act which changed everything. He said: “I remember about three years into the job I was talking to a patient during a consultation and just turned my computer screen round so they could see what I was typing. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs a newly qualied GP looking for his first post, Dr Amir Hannan thought the cosy little surgery advertised simply as ‘ Market Street, Cheshire’ looked perfect. It was only when he phoned and asked where to send his application that his we realised who used to run the practice. The rookie doctor was stepping into the shoes of Dr Death. It was the surgery in Hyde run by Harold Shipman who murdered around  of his patients, making him the most prolic serial killer in history. The old mill town, seven miles from Manchester, was devastated by the evil doctor’s crimes. He worked and killed there from  until he was caught in , and every resident knew someone whose le had been cruelly cut short by Shipman. It was on January ,  –  years ago today, that he was convicted and jailed for le for murdering  of his patients. Dr Hannan arrived in Hyde nine months later, and was soon all too well aware of what he was letting himself in for. He says: “The day before I started, my we and I were watching TV and it came on the news – they were in  Market Street in Hyde and there were a whole load of elderly men and women all sat on the floor of the waiting room. They were angry, protesting that a new doctor was going to be foisted upon them. I just thought, ‘Oh my God – I am walking into a war zone’. “That gave me my first taste of what was going to come. I arrived to find that Shipman’s we had turned up the night before and taken the computer system away because it had been owned by Shipman.” Giving his new premises a thorough examination, like any good doctor, it was Dr Hannan’s heart which suddenly skipped a beat when he stumbled across the couch on which Shipman had murdered a number of his patients. He says: “There was a side room off the surgery that had the couch in it. He had put the patients in there, murdered them, shut the door and then carried on his consultations and nobody knew. So there I am on day one, I have no computer, and that couch had to go immediately.” Shipman hid in plain sight, murdering mostly elderly female patients. His killing method was injecting diamorphine, a pharmaceutical heroin. Born in Nottingham in , as a boy he was very close to his domineering mother Vera. Chillingly given his subsequent killing spree, he was fascinated by how morphine eased Vera’s pain when she was dying from lung cancer.  His mother died aged just  when Shipman was . Determined to become a doctor, he graduated from Leeds School of Medicine in , four years after marrying Primrose Oxtoby, with whom he would have four children. After finishing his training, he joined a practice in Todmorden, West Yorks. Shipman’s career almost came to an abrupt and early halt. He became addicted to the painkiller Pethidine and was caught forging prescriptions. He left the practice and entered drug rehab, hit with a fine and a conviction for forgery. But the General Medical Council decided no further action should be taken, as did the Home Office. Shipman was free toto the profession and in  secured a post at the Donneybrook practice in Hyde. He became known as a hardworking, honest GP and in , after more than a decade at Donneybrook, set out on his own, starting up the practice in Market Street.  He was followed by devoted patients, many of whom would later refuse to believe the man they thought of as a pillar of the community was an angel of death.  It was March  when it became apparent Shipman’s elderly patients were dying at a higher rate than expected and in very similar circumstances – usually fully clothed, sitting up in an armchair or reclining on a settee. Despite respected members of the community – a funeral director, a taxi driver and another GP, becoming suspicious, a preliminary police investigation said there was no cause for concern. Shipman’s records appeared to be in order and little wonder, for the doctor had carefully falsied them.  In the end the family GP would finally be snared by his own greed. In June ,  year-old former mayoress of Hyde Kathleen Grundy was discovered dead hours after Shipman visited, leaving relatives perplexed as she had appeared to be in good health. They were further alarmed when they discovered her will had been changed, leaving her whole estate, worth £,, to Shipman. The doctor insisted no autopsy was necessary but Kathleen’s daughter Angela Woodruff refused to accept Dr Shipman’s explanations. Her mother’s body was exhumed and a postmortem revealed she died from a morphine overdose administered within three hours of her death.  Matching the time frame in which Shipman had visited her, the doctor’s home was searched and medical records, a strange collection of jewellery and the typewriter used to forge the will were uncovered. Police soon learned the calculating killer had urged many families to get their loved ones cremated to hide his crimes, produced falsied medical notes when questions were raised – and even pretended to call the emergency services in front of relatives only to “cancel” the ambulance after he pronounced the patient dead. Shipman went on trial at Preston crown court charged with  counts of murder and one count of forgery and was found guilty on all charges.  The disgraced doctor was given a whole le sentence and four years later, he hung himself at Wakefield Prison, aged . He remains the only British doctor ever to be found guilty of murdering his patients. The subsequent Shipman Inquiry looked into how he had got away with killing for so long, and why he had done it. But in the end its chair Dame Janet Smith said: “I think Shipman’s crimes were without motive. “The psychiatrists warn me that it is possible that, in Shipman’s own mind, there was a conscious motivation. All I can say is that there is no evidence of any of the features that I have observed, in my experience as a judge, that motivate murderers.”  What is clear is that Shipman’s killing spree shattered trust among his patients in Hyde – which Dr Hannan has been rebuilding. The -year-old GP says: “When the story first broke it was complete disbelief. People said no, you go to your doctor for him to help you, not for him to murder you. “This is a deprived area. People here die  years earlier than the national average which is one of the reasons nobody picked up on the excess deaths. It was almost, what do you expect  You live in Hyde. “It might not be talked about on the news any more, but it is still very vivid in people’s minds and it causes distress and mental health problems. I am still dealing with the fallout of Shipman to this very day. It doesn’t go away.” Ingrid Brindle was one of Shipman’s patients. “I thought he was an excellent doctor because I had a long-term medical condition and he gave me everything I needed,” she says. “I really thought he was excellent and so did a lot of other people.” It was important for Dr Hannan to regain the trust of his patients. It was one simple act which changed everything. He said: “I remember about three years into the job I was talking to a patient during a consultation and just turned my computer screen round so they could see what I was typing. As I turned that screen around there was a flicker of a smile I had never seen before.” From then on Dr Hannan, who has moved to the new Haughton Thornley Medical Centre in the town, gave every patient access to their medical records, and ensured that they understood them. He says: “It’s possible Shipman convinced his victims, ‘Well, you’ve got heart disease so that is why I am giving you this morphine’. And they just went along with it, because why would you question a doctor ”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A shocking picture of a young girl sleeping on a hospital floor with suspected meningitis has been shared on social media.It is thought the girl, believed to be eight years old, was at the Raigmore Hospital in Inverness, Scotland on Tuesday night.A photo was shared on Facebook of her lying curled up on a jacket on the floor of the AE department while she was waiting to be assessed for possible meningitis. It is claimed she was not offered a bed or even given a blanket, despite having to wait six hours for treatment. Now hospital bosses are urging the parents of the photographed girl to come forwards to have a confidential discussion about what happened. The youngster apparently had a suspicious rash but was discharged after being diagnosed with a common cold. But then a woman called Denise McLean, who claimed to be a friend of the childaposs grandparents, shared the photo of her lying on the floor on Facebook. Alongside the photo Denise wrote: A very big message to our politicians. Our children deserve better in January . Stop talking and do something please!!!. She added: “The forgotten child. This eight-year-old deserved better at AE last night. No beds. No blanket given, and sleeping on her jacket. NHS Highland – six hours of uncare. The photo has now been removed but not before the hospital saw it, which is why they are now pleading for the childaposs parentaposs to come forward. Katherine Sutton, head of acute services for NHS Highland, said: Our emergency department provides high-quality care for all patients that attend.  This is done through an initial clinical assessment that identies the appropriate treatment and care required to meet patient need. We have become aware of an image that is circulating on social media and are looking into the circumstances. The parent has not been in touch with us to raise any concerns and we would encourage them to contact our feedback team in order to have a confidential discussion with them directly and identy any opportunities to improve our services. Highland MSP Kate Forbes said: One of the most distressing experiences for any parent is when their young child is ill, and it is at times like these that we are reminded how immensely thankful we should be to live in a country with healthcare free at the point of need. Doctors, nurses and medical staff work round the clock to provide emergency care, and the work they do is nothing short of heroic.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Britain is standing at a critical junction in historyAs Britain leaves the EU it stands at a critical juncture in its history, with trade deals needing to be struck with United States, Australia, India and Japan for the country to prosperShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JAN NewsopinionPeople gather in Parliament Square to celebrate the United Kingdoms departure from the European Union " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritain at a crossroads The United Kingdom today stands at a critical juncture. At pm last night we waved goodbye to our -year membership of the EU. Many will embark on this uncertain journey with optimism, others with trepidation, but everyone realises this is a decisive moment. The immediate task is to secure a new trade deal with the European Union which protects jobs and business. There must be no undermining of environmental and consumer protections or chipping away at hard-won workers’ rights. We also need to strike new trade agreements with dozens of other countries including the United States, Australia, India and Japan. In this instance no-deal would be better than a bad dealit meant giving US firms access to the NHS or allowed America to export its chlorinated chicken and hormone-pumped beef to these shores. Having “taken back control”, Boris Johnson’s Government must build a fairer Britain which spreads wealth more evenly and leaves no area of Britain behind. The “levelling up” he promises would not be necessarythe Conservatives had not waged a war of austerity which has hollowed out communities and starved vital services. Mr Johnson claims this is a moment to improve lives in every corner of the UK. The Mirror will be watching to make sure the Prime Minister makes good on his word.  Trust the NHS THE coronavirus came to our shores yesterday with the confirmation that two people have tested positive for the ­potentially deadly virus. This will be an anxious time for the patients and the  Britons in quarantine after being flown back from Wuhan yesterday.

At four months old, the little boy with an infectious smile was diagnosed with the rare, le-limiting brain disorder lissencephaly. “I can’t praise Acorns enough,” says his mum Hayley, . “In dficult times they’ve been there for us as a family, giving us the support we need. “It’s a home-from-home environment, full of smiles, courage and laughter. All the nurses at Acorns make every moment count.” Now all the family want for Jude’s third birthday tomorrow is for their local Acorns in Walsall to stay open. One of many hospices across the country threatened with closure as Britain faces an end-of-le care crisis, Acorns’ shortage of NHS funding means it is increasingly reliant on donations and charity shops. It needs to raise £million to continue to support families across the Black Country. “If Acorns closed, we, as a family, would be devastated,” Hayley says. “The hospice doesn’t only support and provide respite for Jude, it provides emotional support for my entire family, especially our other two children.” As part of its long-term plan, NHS England has pledged to raise funding for children’s hospices to £million in  , and the Conservative Party pledged to “support our precious hospices” in its election manesto. But hospice and healthcare charity Sue Ryder says this is a “sticking plaster” and that “warm words do not begin to address the underlying problems”. This week Sue Ryder’s chief executive Heidi Travis issued a stark warning: “Without radical reform, UK hospices providing end-of-le care to the ­terminally ill and support to their ­families, cannot survive,” she said. “In short, people who need palliative care will not receive it.”  Travis called for an “urgent, detailed review of funding for the UK’s hospices” and an end to “the postcode lottery of palliative care”. A report from Together For Short Lives, a group which represents hospice users, warns of a “children’s palliative care workforce crisis”. It says services are at “breaking point” because of a growing shortage of palliative care doctors and nurses. The report shows there are just  children’s palliative care consultants in the UK when there should be  to . Meanwhile, one in eight nursing jobs in the sector are currently vacant. The Royal College of Nursing recommends there should be around , community children’s nurses in England, but the NHS only has . “The children’s palliative care ­workforce is at breaking point,” says Together for Short Lives’ boss Andy Fletcher. “Terminally ill children and their families are missing out on the round-the-clock care they need. Services are struggling with a dangerous mix of growing staff shortages and rising ­caseloads.” Hospices UK says funding for the end-of-le care system as a whole is “broken”. And eight in  charitable hospices surveyed by Hospices UK say they are planning a deficit budget this financial year. Meanwhile, Professor David Clark at the University of Glasgow has estimated hospices are currently “propping up the NHS to the tune of £billion in care” every year. Acorns supports  children and their families at its Walsall hospice each year, and  in total here and at its other two hospices in Selly Oak, Birmingham, and Worcester. Staff provide day, end-of-le and overnight care, as well as bereavement counselling.  For Rachel O’Donnell and Jonathon Waring, the hospice is how their family survives. Rachel has multiple sclerosis. Their seven-year-old son, Charlie, suffers from a rare chromosome disorder which means he needs round-the-clock, one-to-one care. Acorns provides the respite care that allows the family to keep looking after Charlie at home. “It is exhausting looking after Charlie,” Rachel, , says. “I have MS and some days I find it hard to get out of bed. We had help from the Hospice at Home service, where carers would come in while we had a bit of respite, but due to funding cuts this is no longer available. “The overnight respite is when Charlie comes to Acorns. This allows us to spend time with our younger daughter. “When I’m hospitalised with my MS, I know they can support us. If it closed it would be impossible for us to travel to Worcester or Birmingham.” Mark Lyttle and his ex-partner Jen Dalton turned to the Walsall hospice when their three-year-old daughter, Isabella, was diagnosed with cancer. By the time she passed away aged , the hospice had become their second home. “Without Acorns, we wouldn’t be here today,” says Mark, . “Jen and myself gave up work to look after Isabella. We were so exhausted, some days I could not even remember my own name.” But Acorns’ chief executive Toby Porter says in the past year the hospice faced the “perfect storm”. “We saw a sharp decline in our shop income as well as in donations from big businesses,” he says. “There was uncertainty around Brexit too.”A spokesman for the Department of Health and Social Care said: “End of le care is vitally important, and the NHS is committed to caring for people from cradle to grave. Last year the Prime Minister announced a £million cash injection to protect hospices and palliative care services so people across the country will have the best, most personalised and dignied choices when they die.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA newborn baby was left with a gash on her face after doctors accidentally cut her during a caesarean section. The incident took place at a public hospital in the city of Kyshtym in south-western Russia’s Chelyabinsk Oblast region when -year-old Darya Kadochnikova was giving birth. Darya was taken to the hospital and had planned a normal birth but doctors decided a caesarean section would be safer after her baby changed position. Local media report that doctors initially gave Darya epidural anaesthesia but since she could still feel everything, the medical team had to sedate the patient by giving her an intravenous anaesthesia. After waking up Darya was shocked to see a large cut on her daughter’s face. The doctors have told the mother that her newborn girl shouldn’t have moved too much. The mother herself reportedly suffered from a high fever following her C-section.  She is reportedly still breastfeeding her daughter despite taking antibiotics. The hospital is yet to comment on the incident.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe skeleton of a reptile that roamed Earth  million years ago and crushed the bones of its prey has been found in Brazil. The terrying ft-long creature, an ancestor of the crocodile, was the “T-Rex of its time”, according to researchers. Named dynamosuchus collisensis, it walked on four legs but used its two hind limbs to run, had powerful jaws with blade-like teeth and ­razor-sharp claws that ripped flesh open. The well-preserved remains were found at Agudo in southern Brazil. ­Expedition leader Dr Rodrigo Muller said: “The extremely rare reptile would have been a real bonecrusher from the dawn of the dinosaur era. “Their large teeth were adapted to eat meat. But the bite speed was low, suggesting it was also a scavenger.” The beast’s skull is similar to that of T-Rex, which came almost  million years later. Dr Muller, a biologist at Brazil’s Federal University of Santa Maria, added: “During the late Triassic, while the first dinosaurs were fighting over small prey, dynamosuchus collisensis was probably searching for carcasses or easy to catch animals, like today’s vultures and hyenas do.  “Some palaeontologists say T-Rex did the same. It also had a good sense of smell, and was probably slow. So both occupied a similar role.”
